admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
subsc: General industry and trade sector,Central government administration,Banking,Law and justice,Payments, settlements, and remittance systems
trustfund: TF023077-PHRD-SOCIAL SAFETY NET 7 HUMAN RESOURCES,TF028518-EAS - KAZAKHSTAN

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, and the
            institutional development impact substantial. Key lessons
            address the importance of linking technical assistance (TA)
            activities to specific policy reform operations, exemplified
            by the project's readily available funding, and
            speediness of Bank technical specialists, not only in
            helping the Government undertake policy reform issues, but
            in understanding procurement guidelines, thus allowing major
            contributions to the preparation of up-coming operations.
            However, the borrower should outline the role of beneficiary
            agencies for achieving development objectives, and
            institutional capacity, since the insufficient attention to
            functional analysis of the beneficiary agencies in the
            original project design, hindered greater success.
            Nonetheless, as demonstrated by their positive results,
            moderate, targeted consultant assignments deliver more
            effective, and tangible results, and tend to be procured
            much faster than large assignments which cover large numbers
            of subject matters. Close supervision of TA loans is a
            critical element to the success of the project, which should
            be conducted by high level professional Bank staff, to
            involve a meaningful dialogue with the Borrower, and provide
            advice to the Government. The satisfactory supervision
            results of the environment sub-component is a good example
            of such assistance.
